title: John Cooper (British Army officer)
text:
<a href="Lieutenant-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Lieutenant General</a> John Cooper, (born 17 February 1955) is a former senior <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer. From March 2008 he was the Deputy Commander of <a href="Multinational%20force%20in%20Iraq">Multinational Force-Iraq</a> (MNF-I), the operational-level headquarters in Iraq, and the Senior British Military Representative-Iraq. As Deputy Commander, he was the principal assistant to General <a href="Raymond%20T.%20Odierno">Raymond T. Odierno</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>. He stepped down on 4 March 2009, and retired from the army later that year.
Early life and career.
Cooper was born on 17 February 1955 in <a href="Berwick-upon-Tweed">Berwick-upon-Tweed</a>. Educated at Berwick Grammar School, he then went to <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>, and was commissioned into the <a href="King%27s%20Own%20Scottish%20Borderers">King's Own Scottish Borderers</a> (KOSB) as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> on 8 March 1975. He initially served in <a href="Operation%20Banner">Northern Ireland</a>, Britain and Germany, he was promoted <a href="first%20lieutenant">lieutenant</a> on 8 March 1977, and <a href="captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> on 8 September 1981. In the early 1980s he served two tours with a British Army advisory and training team in Zimbabwe before attending <a href="Staff%20College%2C%20Camberley">Staff College, Camberley</a> in 1987. He was promoted <a href="major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> on 30 September 1987, and after graduation from the staff course, he was appointed <a href="Chief%20of%20Staff">Chief of Staff</a>, <a href="8th%20Infantry%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">8th Infantry Brigade</a> in Northern Ireland 1988–89, for which he was appointed <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Member of the Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE) on 6 November 1990. He then commanded a rifle company in 1st Battalion, KOSB (1KOSB), including active service in the <a href="Gulf%20War">Gulf War</a>. He was promoted <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a> on 30 June 1994, and commanded 1KOSB for a further tour in Northern Ireland, for which he was appointed to the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO), as well as tours in Edinburgh and Lancashire. He then served as an instructor at the Staff College, Camberley, and at the <a href="Joint%20Services%20Command%20and%20Staff%20College">Joint Services Command and Staff College</a>.
Higher command.
In November 1997, Cooper was appointed to a high staff position as Deputy Assistant Chief of Staff, G3 (O&D) in <a href="Commander%20Land%20Forces">HQ LAND</a>, where he had responsibility for implementing recommendations arising from the <a href="Strategic%20Defence%20Review">Strategic Defence Review</a>. He attended the <a href="Higher%20Command%20and%20Staff%20Course">Higher Command and Staff Course</a> in 1998, and was promoted <a href="colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> on 30 June 1998. He was officially promoted to <a href="brigadier">brigadier</a> on 31 December 1999, with seniority from 30 June 1999, having taken command of the <a href="12th%20Mechanised%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">12th Mechanised Brigade</a> in November 1999. The brigade deployed to Bosnia in 2000. He was appointed to the honorary position of KOSB's Colonel of the Regiment on 9 February 2001 and held that post until the regiment was disbanded with its merger into the <a href="Royal%20Regiment%20of%20Scotland">Royal Regiment of Scotland</a> on 28 March 2006, when he became a Deputy Colonel of the new regiment. He was appointed the <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20Defence%20Staff%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Chief of the Defence Staff</a>'s <a href="liaison%20officer">liaison officer</a> to the <a href="Chairman%20of%20the%20Joint%20Chiefs%20of%20Staff">Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff</a> in the <a href="Pentagon%20%28United%20States%29">Pentagon (United States)</a> in Washington DC in 2002. He then assumed the appointment of Chief of Staff, Field Army, HQ Land Command.
Upon promotion to <a href="Major%20General%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major general</a> on 7 May 2004, Cooper became Deputy Commander Combined Forces Command (<a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>) until December 2004. He was awarded the US <a href="Bronze%20Star%20Medal">Bronze Star Medal</a> for his service in Afghanistan. When he departed Afghanistan, he took command of <a href="1st%20Armoured%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st (UK) Armoured Division</a> on 25 January 2005, taking elements of that division to Iraq where it formed HQ <a href="Multi-National%20Division%20%28South-East%29%20%28Iraq%29">Multi-National Division (South-East)</a>. He returned to England for two years of senior leadership positions before his promotion to lieutenant general and return to Iraq on 23 March 2008 to become <a href="Multi-National%20Force%20%E2%80%93%20Iraq">Senior British Military Representative and Deputy Commanding General, Multinational Force, Iraq</a>. He stepped down from the post on 4 March 2009. In an interview on 3 March 2009 he expressed his belief that the struggle against Al Qaida in Iraq had been won, and that the country was getting back on its feet.
Cooper was appointed <a href="Companion%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Companion of the Order of the Bath</a> (CB) in the 2009 Birthday Honours. He retired from the army on 21 November 2009.
